program_name: CPS Energy Summer Demand Response Program
description: CPS Energy's Summer Demand Response Program operates from June 1 through September 30, offering multiple participation options for residential, small business, and commercial/industrial customers. Residential customers participate via WiFi Thermostat Rewards programs (including brand-specific options like Nest Rush Hour Rewards), receiving bill credits for allowing CPS Energy to briefly adjust thermostats during conservation events. Small businesses earn payments for voluntary load reduction during events with 30-minute or 2-hour notice options. Commercial/industrial customers can earn higher payments based on faster response times. The program is part of CPS Energy's STEP (Sustainable Tomorrow Energy Plan) initiative to achieve 410 MW of incremental demand reduction by 2027.

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Program has three distinct participation tiers: (1) Residential customers with WiFi thermostats controlling central A/C systems, (2) Small businesses eligible for My Business Rewards DR, (3) Large commercial/industrial customers eligible for Commercial DR program with kW-based payments.

additional_requirements: Residential: Must have CPS Energy-approved WiFi thermostat controlling central air conditioning
Small Business: Must provide business name, service address, and CPS Energy account number
Battery Storage Pilot: Currently limited to approximately 1,800 residential battery storage system owners
Cannot participate in ERCOT programs simultaneously (implied)

notice_details.residential_thermostat: Events triggered automatically, customers may receive notification but thermostat adjusts automatically

enrollment_credit.description: One-time bill credit per enrolled thermostat. Historical rates: $150 (Nov 2018 - Oct 2019), $85 (Nov 2019 - present). Multiple thermostats can be enrolled.

annual_credit.description: Annual bill credit applied in October/November following the end of September. Paid per household/business account, not per thermostat.

residential_thermostat_program.payment_timing: Enrollment credit within 1-2 billing cycles. Annual credit appears on October/November bill.

30_minute_option.description: Earn $73 per kW of load reduction with 30-minute advance notice

2_hour_option.description: Earn $70 per kW of load reduction with 2-hour advance notice

bonus_hours_option.description: Additional evening events (7-10 PM) with 30-minute notice, 16 additional events available

small_business_program.payment_timing: End-of-season incentive payment based on performance

commercial_industrial_program.description: CPS Energy pays participants based on electricity reduction during events compared to normal usage. Specific per-kW rates not publicly disclosed on primary sources.
commercial_industrial_program.payment_basis: kW reduction measured via meter data
commercial_industrial_program.payment_timing: Performance feedback after each event, payment at end of season

battery_storage_pilot.description: Residential battery storage system owners receive $20 credit per participation event when they shift power load from grid to battery during peak demand

penalty_structure.penalty_description: No penalties for non-performance. Participation is voluntary and customers can opt out of events at any time.

seasons.notes: Approximately 25 conservation events per season, typically lasting 3 hours each. Events occur on weekdays (some programs allow weekend events). Total of approximately 75 hours per summer season.
No summer demand response events during off-peak months. Note: CPS Energy operates a separate Winter Demand Response Program (December 1 - March 30).

call_windows.notes: Residential thermostat program: Events typically occur 1 PM - 10 PM during hot summer months. Precooling may begin 30 minutes to 1 hour before setback period.
Small Business and Commercial DR: Events occur 1 PM - 7 PM on weekdays during June 1 - September 30 period.
Small Business Rewards Bonus Hours: Additional 16 events available 7-10 PM with $10/kW payment for load reduction.

additional_details.residential_precooling: Thermostats may precool homes 30 minutes to 1 hour before setback period begins
additional_details.residential_setback: Temperature setback of a few degrees applied after precooling, duration varies by event
additional_details.notification_flexibility: Customers choose between 30-minute or 2-hour notice options for small business program

enrollment_period.notes: Rolling enrollment available. Residential customers enroll through thermostat manufacturer platforms or CPS Energy website. Small business customers contact CPS Energy at (210) 353-2728. Customers can withdraw at any time.

residential: Purchase and install CPS Energy-approved WiFi thermostat
Enroll online through manufacturer platform (Nest, ecobee, Honeywell, etc.) or thermostatrewards.com/cps
Connect thermostat to WiFi and home cooling system
Allow CPS Energy to adjust thermostat during peak periods
Receive enrollment credit within 1-2 billing cycles
small_business: Contact CPS Energy at (210) 353-2728 or email demand.response@cpsenergy.com
Provide business name, service address, and CPS Energy account number
Choose between 30-minute notice ($73/kW) or 2-hour notice ($70/kW) option
Optionally enroll in Bonus Hours program ($10/kW, 7-10 PM)
commercial_industrial: Contact CPS Energy account manager or email demand.response@cpsenergy.com
Discuss load reduction capabilities and baseline establishment
Begin participation, receive performance feedback after each event

performance_measurement.residential_thermostat: Automated thermostat adjustment verified through smart thermostat data
performance_measurement.commercial_baseline: Load reduction calculated by comparing event-period consumption to normal baseline usage
performance_measurement.meter_data: AMI (Advanced Metering Infrastructure) meter data used for measurement and verification
performance_measurement.feedback: Commercial/business participants receive performance feedback after each event
performance_measurement.annual_reporting: End-of-season incentive calculations provided to participants

battery_storage_pilot.description: Pilot program targeting residential battery storage owners. CPS Energy contacts participants during peak demand to request voluntary shift from grid to battery power. Likely to expand to summer program after winter testing.

step_program_context.progress_as_of_2024: 216 MW achieved (more than halfway to goal)

program_evolution.change_description: WiFi Thermostat Rewards offered $150 enrollment credit (Nov 23, 2018 - Oct 31, 2019)
Enrollment credit reduced to $85 per thermostat (effective Nov 1, 2019)
STEP (Sustainable Tomorrow Energy Plan) authorized by City of San Antonio, formalizing 410 MW demand reduction goal by 2027
Winter Demand Response Program launched (December 2023 - March 2024), battery storage pilot initiated with $20 per event payment

program_history.program_cost_estimate: Up to $4.5 million in annual payouts and credits for winter program; summer program cost not specifically disclosed
program_history.notes: CPS Energy's demand response programs have enrolled more customers than any other utility in Texas. Thermostat program achieved 100 MW demand reduction. Combined winter program targets 42 MW (thermostats) + 9.8 MW (batteries).

participation_statistics.notes: CPS Energy has more demand response customers than any other utility in Texas. 150,000 thermostats enrolled as of winter 2024 program launch.

residential_thermostat_mechanics.precooling: Legacy users: 30-60 minutes. Eco+ users: customized duration per home.
residential_thermostat_mechanics.setback: Temperature raised by a few degrees during peak demand
residential_thermostat_mechanics.override: Customers can opt out at any time by adjusting thermostat, setting hold, or ending eco+ for the day
residential_thermostat_mechanics.comfort: Minimal impact on comfort, adjustments only by a few degrees

small_business_curtailment_methods: Adjust temperature setpoints / reduce air conditioning
Turn off unused computers and equipment
program_operations.commercial_industrial_methods: Load reduction strategies vary by customer type and capabilities
customer_rights: Can opt out of any event at any time
Can terminate enrollment at any time
utility_controls: CPS Energy can adjust enrolled thermostats during conservation events
Events triggered based on grid conditions and peak demand forecasts
No guarantee of specific number of events

data_sources.source_name: CPS Energy WiFi Thermostat Rewards Main Page
data_sources.notes: Official program page with enrollment details, eligible devices, and payment structure

data_sources.source_name: CPS Energy Nest Rush Hour Rewards Page
data_sources.notes: Nest-specific program page with enrollment process and payment details

data_sources.source_name: CPS Energy Commercial Demand Response Page
data_sources.notes: Commercial/industrial DR program details including season dates, event windows, and notification requirements

data_sources.source_name: CPS Energy My Business Rewards Demand Response Page
data_sources.notes: Small business DR program with specific payment rates ($73/kW 30-min, $70/kW 2-hour, $10/kW bonus hours)
Detailed terms and conditions including historical payment rates and program start date (Sept 1, 2015)
Technical details on precooling duration and event mechanics for ecobee thermostats

data_sources.source_name: San Antonio Report: CPS Energy Winter Demand Response Program Explainer
data_sources.notes: Detailed article on winter program including battery storage pilot, commercial/industrial rates, and program costs. Provides context for summer program structure.

data_sources.source_name: Express-News: CPS Energy Battery Storage Program
data_sources.notes: Article on battery storage pilot program with $20 per event payment

data_sources.source_name: Express-News: CPS Energy STEP Program Progress
data_sources.notes: Article on STEP program progress: 216 MW achieved (more than halfway to 410 MW goal), $143.4M spent of $350M budget

data_sources.source_name: Utility Dive: CPS Energy Smart Thermostat Program Case Study
data_sources.notes: Article confirming CPS Energy achieved 100 MW demand reduction through thermostat program

integration_metadata.notes: Good quality program documentation with clear residential payment rates and small business rates. Commercial/industrial per-kW rates not publicly disclosed. Multiple customer tiers create complexity for modeling. Residential program primarily thermostat-based with limited battery storage pilot. Small business program has clear $73/kW (30-min) and $70/kW (2-hour) rates plus $10/kW bonus hours option.
optimization_considerations: Residential thermostat program has limited applicability for battery optimization (customer cannot directly control dispatch)
Battery storage pilot offers $20 per event but is voluntary call-based, not automated
Small business program offers clear capacity payments: $73/kW (30-min notice) or $70/kW (2-hour notice)
Bonus hours program ($10/kW, 7-10 PM) provides additional revenue opportunity with 16 events
Events limited to 1-7 PM primary window (with 7-10 PM bonus option) during June-September
Approximately 25 primary events + 16 bonus events = 41 total event opportunities per season
Behind-the-meter batteries eligible for commercial/business programs if providing load curtailment
No penalties for non-performance encourages participation but may reduce dispatch reliability
Customer can opt out of any event, creating uncertainty for optimization models
ERCOT market participation restrictions may apply (cannot simultaneously participate in ERS)
integration_metadata.program_comparison_notes: CPS Energy operates separate summer (June-Sept) and winter (Dec-March) DR programs. Summer program is more mature with 150,000 thermostats enrolled. Battery storage pilot launched in winter 2024 and may expand to summer. CPS Energy has largest DR customer base in Texas. Program is part of broader STEP initiative with 410 MW goal by 2027, currently at 216 MW (54% complete).

critical_program_details.municipal_ownership: Owned by City of San Antonio, largest municipal utility in Texas
critical_program_details.step_program_relationship: Summer DR is integral component of STEP (Sustainable Tomorrow Energy Plan) to achieve 410 MW demand reduction by 2027
critical_program_details.customer_base: More DR customers than any other utility in Texas (150,000+ thermostats enrolled)
critical_program_details.thermostat_vs_battery: Primary residential program is thermostat-based. Battery storage is pilot program with $20/event payment, not automated dispatch
critical_program_details.commercial_industrial_opacity: Large commercial/industrial per-kW rates not publicly disclosed, must contact CPS Energy
critical_program_details.no_penalties: All programs emphasize voluntary participation with no penalties for non-performance
critical_program_details.customer_override: Customers can always opt out of events, maintaining comfort control
critical_program_details.payment_timing: Residential: enrollment credit in 1-2 billing cycles, annual credit in Oct/Nov. Business: end-of-season payment.
critical_program_details.multiple_enrollment: Residential customers can enroll multiple thermostats, each earning $85 enrollment credit, but only one $30 annual credit per household
critical_program_details.winter_program_exists: Separate winter DR program operates Dec 1 - Mar 30 with different payment structure

research_notes.data_integrity: All data verified from primary sources (CPS Energy official website pages) and reputable secondary sources (San Antonio Report, Express-News). NO INVENTED DATA. Payment rates, season dates, event parameters, and program structure all extracted from official sources.
missing_information: Specific per-kW payment rates for large commercial/industrial customers (only disclosed to enrolled customers)
Exact program launch year for summer DR program (thermostat rewards operating since at least Sept 2015 per terms)
Specific annual budget for summer program (winter program budgeted at $4.5M)
Maximum event duration (only typical 3-hour duration stated)
Baseline calculation methodology for commercial/industrial measurement
Specific eligibility criteria for battery storage pilot enrollment
Historical event call data (number of events per year, actual dispatch times)

clarifications.program_name: CPS Energy does not use a single branded name for 'Summer DR Program'. The program consists of multiple sub-programs: WiFi Thermostat Rewards (residential), Nest Rush Hour Rewards (residential Nest-specific), My Business Rewards Demand Response (small business), Commercial Demand Response (large C&I), and Battery Storage Pilot. All operate during summer season (June-Sept).
clarifications.residential_vs_commercial: Clear segmentation: residential = thermostat-based with fixed bill credits; small business = kW-based payments with choice of notice period; large commercial/industrial = kW-based payments with undisclosed rates.
clarifications.thermostat_brands: Program supports 10+ thermostat brands/models, each with brand-specific enrollment process but same payment structure ($85 enrollment + $30 annual).
clarifications.battery_storage_status: Battery storage pilot launched in winter 2024 for testing. Pays $20 per participation event (not per kW). Likely to expand to summer after winter pilot. Currently ~1,800 eligible customers with 9.8 MW potential capacity.
clarifications.step_context: Summer DR is not standalone program but component of City-authorized STEP initiative. STEP budget: $350M total, $143.4M spent by 2024, targeting 410 MW reduction by 2027 (currently 54% complete at 216 MW).
clarifications.payment_basis: Residential thermostats: fixed bill credits regardless of kW. Small business: $/kW based on actual reduction. This creates different optimization considerations for each tier.
clarifications.bonus_hours: Small business 'Bonus Hours' program (7-10 PM, $10/kW, 16 events) operates in addition to primary 1-7 PM window (25 events), creating total of 41 potential event opportunities.
clarifications.enrollment_flexibility: Rolling enrollment, no fixed enrollment windows. Customers can enroll and withdraw at any time. No penalties for non-performance or withdrawal.
clarifications.municipal_utility_context: CPS Energy is largest municipal utility in Texas, owned by City of San Antonio. Participates in ERCOT wholesale markets but serves retail customers directly. This explains City Council authorization for STEP program.

research_notes.program_complexity_notes: This program is more complex than typical single-tier DR programs due to: (1) multiple customer segments with different payment structures, (2) integration with broader STEP initiative, (3) mix of automated (thermostat) and voluntary (business) dispatch, (4) battery storage pilot in development, (5) separate winter counterpart program. However, core structure is straightforward: June-Sept season, 1-7 PM primary window, ~25 events, voluntary participation.
research_notes.relationship_to_other_programs: This is distinct from CPS Energy's Winter Demand Response Program (Dec-March) but uses similar structure. Also distinct from Austin Energy's Commercial DR program (researched in batch3_006) despite both being Texas municipal utilities in ERCOT. CPS Energy program has larger customer base and more mature residential component.
research_notes.data_quality_assessment: Primary source documentation is excellent for residential and small business tiers. Commercial/industrial tier has less public information (per-kW rates not disclosed). Battery storage pilot is new with limited documentation. Overall confidence in accuracy: 9/10 for residential, 8/10 for small business, 6/10 for commercial/industrial, 7/10 for battery pilot.
